intro: Schomburgkia crispa var. wallisii, commonly known as the Wallis’s spider orchid, is a rare and striking orchid native to the rainforests of Queensland, Australia. It is characterized by its long, thin, spider-like inflorescence that bears numerous small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, clinging to trees in the humid, shaded understory of its native habitat. Its foliage consists of narrow, strap-like leaves that are often covered in a dense layer of fine, white pubescence. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species and is of significant interest to botanists and conservationists.
